text: With AI, it's just intensified because you have 10 players pursuing the same market opportunity and so your ability to actually bring the product to market to differentiate yourself from the competition has become more strategically important than it was previously.
speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
context: Lenny mentions he's been getting many requests for go-to-market help lately. Jeanne explains why go-to-market has become increasingly critical in today's business environment. She points out that AI has created intense competition, with multiple companies often targeting the same opportunities, making effective product commercialization and competitive differentiation essential for success.
text_ko: 인공지능(AI) 때문에 상황이 더 심해졌어요. 같은 시장 기회(market opportunity)를 10개 업체가 동시에 쫓고 있으니, 실제로 제품을 시장에 내놓는 능력, 즉 시장 출시(go-to-market) 역량으로 경쟁자들과 차별화하는 게 예전보다 훨씬 전략적으로 중요해졌어요.
text_zh: 有了AI以后，这种情况就更激烈了，因为现在有10个玩家都在争抢同一个市场机会，所以你能不能真正把产品推向市场、从竞争对手中脱颖而出，这个能力比以前更加关键了。
text_es: Con la IA, esto se ha intensificado muchísimo porque tienes 10 jugadores yendo tras la misma oportunidad de mercado, entonces tu capacidad para realmente sacar el producto al mercado y diferenciarte de la competencia se ha vuelto mucho más estratégicamente importante de lo que era antes.

text: 80% of customers buy to avoid pain or reduce risk as opposed to increased upside, which is a good thing for startup founders to understand. We all love to talk about the art of the possible, everything we're going to enable in the future, but that's often really a sale that's going to resonate with another founder.
speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
context: Lenny references advice from Jenna Abel about focusing on competitive advantages rather than just problem-solving. Jeanne shares a crucial insight about customer buying behavior - that most enterprise customers are primarily motivated by risk reduction rather than potential gains. She explains that while founders love discussing future possibilities and innovation, this approach mainly appeals to other founders rather than typical enterprise buyers.
text_ko: 고객의 약 80%는 더 큰 이익(upside)을 기대해서 사는 게 아니라, 고통을 피하거나 위험(risk)을 줄이기 위해 구매해요. 이건 스타트업 창업자들이 꼭 알아둬야 할 포인트예요. 우리 모두는 앞으로 가능해질 것들, 즉 '가능성의 예술(art of the possible)' 같은 얘기를 하길 좋아하지만, 그런 얘기는 실제로는 대개 다른 창업자에게만 공감되는 영업이에요.
text_zh: 80%的客户买产品都是为了避免麻烦或者降低风险，而不是为了获得更多收益，这一点创业者一定要搞清楚。我们都喜欢谈论各种可能性，谈论我们将来能实现什么，但这种销售话术(pitch)往往只对其他创业者有用。
text_es: El 80% de los clientes compran para evitarse dolores de cabeza o reducir riesgos, no tanto por conseguir más beneficios, y esto es algo súper importante que los fundadores de startups tienen que entender. A todos nos encanta hablar de las posibilidades infinitas, de todo lo que vamos a hacer posible en el futuro, pero la realidad es que ese discurso le va a llegar más que nada a otro fundador.

text: The litmus test I have always given my sales team is if you are an account executive in my org and I put you in front of 10 engineers at our company, it should take them 10 minutes to figure out you aren't a product manager.
speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
context: Lenny mentions feedback from people who've worked with Jeanne about her superpower of building sales organizations that engineers appreciate. Jeanne explains her philosophy for creating sales teams that work well with technical teams. She describes her standard for sales excellence - that account executives should have such deep product knowledge and technical understanding that engineers would initially mistake them for product managers.
text_ko: 제가 영업팀에게 항상 제시하는 판별 기준은 이거예요. 우리 조직에서 영업 담당자(account executive)로 일하는 사람이 회사 엔지니어들(engineers) 10명 앞에 서 있으면, 그 사람들이 '이 사람은 제품 관리자(product manager)가 아니다'라는 걸 알아차리는 데 10분이면 충분해야 해요.
text_zh: 我一直给销售团队的试金石就是：如果你是我们组织里的客户经理(account executive)，我让你去跟公司10个工程师聊天，他们应该要花10分钟才能发现你其实不是产品经理。
text_es: La prueba definitiva que siempre les doy a mi equipo de ventas es esta: si eres ejecutivo de cuentas en mi organización y te pongo frente a 10 ingenieros de nuestra empresa, deberían tardar 10 minutos en darse cuenta de que no eres product manager.

text: Often you're not only making that customer successful, but you're then taking all of that back to your product and engineering organization to figure out, okay, what was generalizable that we ought to build into our offering versus what is something that ultimately is going to be more of a professional service in the fullness of time.
speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
context: Lenny asks about the biggest changes in go-to-market over recent years. Jeanne discusses how AI has made sales more consultative, with companies needing to help customers figure out what to change without knowing exactly what they need. She explains the rise of forward-deployed engineering (a rebranding of professional services) where teams work directly in customer environments to understand their needs and determine what should be built into the core product versus offered as services.
text_ko: 대개 고객을 성공시키는 것뿐만 아니라, 그 경험을 다 프로덕트와 엔지니어링 조직(product and engineering organization)에 가져가서 어떤 부분은 일반화해서(generalizable) 우리 솔루션(offering)에 반영해야 하고, 어떤 부분은 시간이 지나면 결국 전문 서비스(professional service)로 남길지 판단하게 돼요.
text_zh: 很多时候你不光要帮客户把事情做成，还得把从客户那儿学到的东西带回产品和工程团队，然后大家一起琢磨，哪些东西是可以复制的、应该直接做到产品里去的，哪些东西到最后还是得走专业服务(professional service)这条路。
text_es: Muchas veces no solo estás logrando que ese cliente tenga éxito, sino que también llevas todo eso de vuelta a tu equipo de producto e ingeniería para analizar: "Oye, ¿qué de esto se puede generalizar y deberíamos integrar en nuestra oferta versus qué es algo que al final va a ser más bien un servicio profesional a largo plazo?"

text: So it wasn't like this was a multi-quarter process, it actually moved super quickly and then again now we just sort of keep that agent manager working with the agent to get it to a point where we say, 'Hey, we're ready to roll.'
speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
context: Lenny expresses amazement at Jeanne's story about reducing their SDR team from 10 people to 1 through AI automation. Jeanne explains the timeline and impact of implementing their lead agent - a single go-to-market engineer spent just 25-30% of their time over six weeks to create an AI system that could handle the workload of 10 sales development representatives, while maintaining the same conversion rates and improving response times.
text_ko: 그러니까 몇 분기씩 걸리는 프로세스는 아니었고, 실제로 굉장히 빠르게 진행됐어요. 지금은 에이전트 매니저(agent manager)가 에이전트(agent)랑 계속 같이 작업해서 우리가 “이제 시작해도 되겠다”라고 말할 수 있는 수준까지 만들어 가고 있어요.
text_zh: 所以这个过程并不是要搞好几个季度那么久，实际上推进得特别快，然后现在我们就是让那个智能体管理器(agent manager)跟智能体(agent)一直配合，直到我们觉得"好了，可以上线了"。
text_es: O sea, no fue como un proceso de varios trimestres, la verdad es que se movió súper rápido y ahora simplemente mantenemos a ese gestor de agentes trabajando con el agente para llegar al punto donde decimos, "Oye, ya estamos listos para arrancar."

text: I struggle with sales comp because it's all about pay for performance, which I'm obviously a fan of, but it makes your organization less flexible because you basically have to decide 12 months in advance, these are things I value and particularly in this moment that could be different.
speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
context: Lenny asks about Jeanne's hot take on sales compensation and hiring practices. Jeanne explains her concern with traditional sales compensation structures. While she supports pay-for-performance principles, she argues that rigid annual compensation plans reduce organizational agility by forcing companies to predetermine priorities a year in advance, which can be problematic in rapidly changing markets where companies need to pivot quickly.
text_ko: 영업 보상(sales comp)에 대해선 고민이에요. 전적으로 성과 기반 보상(pay-for-performance)이라 저도 원칙적으로는 찬성이긴 한데, 조직의 유연성이 떨어져요. 사실상 1년 전에 '이게 우리가 중요하게 생각하는 것들이다'라고 미리 결정해야 하거든요. 특히 지금 같은 시기에는 그 우선순위가 달라질 수도 있는데요.
text_zh: 我对销售薪酬(sales comp)这块挺纠结的，因为它本质上就是按业绩付费，这个理念我肯定是支持的，但问题是这样一来你的组织就没那么灵活了，因为你基本上得提前12个月就定好，哪些东西是我看重的，特别是在现在这种时候，情况随时都可能变。
text_es: Me cuesta trabajo con la compensación de ventas porque se trata de pagar por resultados, lo cual obviamente me parece genial, pero hace que tu organización sea menos flexible porque básicamente tienes que decidir con 12 meses de anticipación cuáles son las cosas que valoras, y especialmente en este momento eso podría ser diferente.
